form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Booker (for himself, Mr. Markey, and Mrs. McCaskill) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

form.official-title: To promote competition, to preserve the ability of local governments to provide broadband capability and services, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Community Broadband Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: the term advanced telecommunications capability has the meaning given the term in section 706(d)(1) of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 (47 U.S.C. 1302(d)(1));
the term advanced telecommunications capability or services means—
the term Indian tribe has the meaning given the term in section 4(e) of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C. 450b(e));

subparagraph.text: a State or political subdivision thereof;
any agency, authority, or instrumentality of a State or political subdivision thereof;
any entity that is owned by, controlled by, or otherwise affiliated with—

clause.text: a State or political subdivision thereof;
an agency, authority, or instrumentality of a State or political subdivision thereof; or

paragraph.text: the term telecommunications service has the meaning given the term in section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 153).

section.header: Local government provision of telecommunications service and advanced telecommunications capability and services
section.text: No statute, regulation, or other legal requirement of a State or local government may prohibit, or have the effect of prohibiting or substantially inhibiting, any public provider from providing telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to any person or any public or private entity.

subsection.text: To the extent any public provider regulates competing providers of telecommunications services or advanced telecommunications capability or services, the public provider shall apply its ordinances, rules, and policies, including those relating to the use of public rights-of-way, permitting, performance bonding, and reporting, without discrimination in favor of—

paragraph.text: any other provider of telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services that the public provider owns or with which the public provider is affiliated.

subsection.text: Nothing in this Act exempts a public provider that offers telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public from any Federal communications law or regulation that applies to all providers of telecommunications services or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public.

section.text: Each public provider that intends to provide telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public is encouraged to consider the potential benefits of a public-private partnership before providing the capability or services.

section.header: Public input and private sector opportunity to bid

subsection.header: Notice and Opportunity To Be Heard
subsection.text: Before a public provider may provide telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public, either directly or through a public-private partnership, the public provider shall—

paragraph.text: publish notice of its intention to do so;
generally describe the capability or services to be provided and the proposed coverage area for the capability or services;
identify any special capabilities or services to be provided in low-income areas or other demographically or geographically defined areas;

provide local citizens and private-sector entities with an opportunity to be heard on the costs and benefits of the project and potential alternatives to the project, including any bids under paragraph (5); and

provide private-sector entities with an opportunity to bid to provide the capability or services during the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the notice required under paragraph (1) is published.

subsection.header: Application to existing projects and pending proposals

paragraph.text: any contract or other arrangement under which a public provider is providing telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public as of the date of enactment of this Act; or
any public provider proposal to provide telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services to the public that, as of the date of enactment of this Act—

subparagraph.text: is in the process of being built; or

section.text: The requirements under sections 4 and 6 shall not apply—

paragraph.text: when a public provider provides telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services other than to the public or to such classes of users as to make the capability or services effectively available to the public; or

during an emergency declared by the President, the Governor of the State in which the public provider is located, or any other elected local official authorized by law to declare a state of emergency in the jurisdiction in which the public provider is located.

section.text: If any project providing telecommunications service or advanced telecommunications capability or services under this Act fails due to bankruptcy or is terminated by a public provider, no Federal funds may be provided to the public provider specifically to assist the public provider in reviving or renewing that project, unless the failure due to bankruptcy occurred in a jurisdiction that is subject to a declaration by the President of a major disaster, as defined in section 102 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5122).
